courseDescription: Required introductory overview to the field of instructional technology.  Topics include a history of the field, basic instructional design, generally accepted theoretical practices and major formats of instructional media.  Emphasis is given to instructional technology trends as applied to various industries, including K-12, military, industry training, and others.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of major formats of instructional media
Application of instructional technology in various industries
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of theoretical practices to diverse audiences
Collaboration in industry training or K-12 settings

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the field of Human Performance Technology (HPT). Students will explore what HPT is, why instructional designers should know about it, how performance improvements can be measured, and most critically, how it can be applied in real environments to solve real problems. Students will gain practice in thinking systematically about performance, and they will enhance their value as instructional design professionals by being able to offer solutions to organizational needs that go beyond traditional instruction.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of HPT in real environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Addressing organizational needs beyond traditional instruction

courseDescription: This course is an applied survey on online instruction, including relevant online learning theory and design considerations, as well as tools and principles, with an emphasis on K-12 education. Topics include theories and principles of online learning, effectively identifying, locating, evaluating, preparing, and using educational technology as instructional resources in an online environment.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying suitable online learning tools and principles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Preparing and organizing online learning materials
Applying online learning theories and principles

courseDescription: This course focuses on the theory, design, and evaluation of measurement instruments used to assess individual knowledge, performance, and attitudes.  Topics include fundamentals of measurement, reliability, validity, and instrument selection, construction, and use.  Students will develop and evaluate instruments for instructional and research purposes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use and construction of instructional and research instruments
Knowledge of reliability and validity in instrument selection
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in instrument design and selection

courseTitle: Principles and Practices of Human Performance Technology
courseDescription: This course explores both the principles and practices of human performance technology, with roughly equal emphasis on both.  Students will learn what HPT is, how it's applied in practice, and how and why instructional designers need to know about it.  Particular emphasis is given to determining whether or not problems are best amenable to instructional solutions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of HPT principles in practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of problems amenable to instructional solutions

courseDescription: This project-based course examines several different non-instructional interventions that can be used to promote performance improvement. Major methodologies common in the field will be explored as a class, and students will also be required to familiarize themselves with other methodologies of their choice. Emphasis will be on the following interventions: job analysis/work design, performance development, human resource development, organizational communication, organizational design and financial systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human resource development mechanisms

courseDescription: This project-based course is designed to develop and enhance the ability of instructional designers to work as partners and consultants to clients and superiors.  The focus is on consulting skills per se, and not any particular content.  All students will be required to do an individual consulting project, supervised by the instructor.

This project-based class will focus on the process of doing a needs analysis and assessment, from start to finish.  Although theoretical considerations regarding needs analyses will be explored, the emphasis is on actually conducting the analysis.  Students will work in teams under the supervision of the instructor to conduct a needs analysis for an external client.

An analysis of the trends, issues, and theories of distance education in education, business, and military applications.  Students will examine various distance education systems, policies and lessons from different perspectives.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical evaluation of distance education policies
Discussion and collaboration on distance education trends
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of trends in distance education
Investigative skills for examining various distance education systems
Critical thinking for assessing issues in distance education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in applying distance education theories
Organization skills for managing distance learning systems
Strategic planning for distance education policies

courseDescription: Students will gain hands-on experience applying a theoretical understanding of instructional design and development to actual projects.  Students will learn and use the Instructional Systems Design Process from initial learner profile analysis to design and development through to evaluation.  Students will work individually and in teams to gain experience similar to real-world instructional design situations. Students will master the fundamental practices upon which the instructional design process is based.

This course covers the theory, design, and evaluation of computer-based multimedia instruction.  Students will demonstrate a thorough understanding of instructional theory and design strategies for computer-based drills, tutorials, hypermedia, simulations, games, tools, open-ended learning environments, tests, and web-based instruction.  Class projects will center on the design and development of instruction utilizing at least two of these methodologies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design and development of computer-based multimedia instruction
Creation and evaluation of computer-based drills
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of design and development projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and improvement of multimedia instruction designs
Strategy formulation for computer-based drills and tutorials
Analyzing and optimizing simulations and game designs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for design and development tasks
Balancing multiple methodologies in a single instruction design

courseTitle: Diffusion and Adoption of Instructional Technology Innovations
courseDescription: This course will explore theories, research, and strategies related to the diffusion and adoption of instructional technology innovations in education and training.  The course will explore why and how individuals, groups, and organizations adopt or fail to adopt an innovation or change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying potential barriers to technology adoption
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Persuading individuals and groups to adopt technology
Communicating the benefits and risks of technology innovations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing why and how innovations are adopted or rejected
Strategic thinking to facilitate technology adoption
Diagnosing problems in the innovation adoption process

courseTitle: Theory and Design of Instructional Simulation
courseDescription: This course focuses on learning theory, design and evaluation of instructional simulations and simulators. Topics include history, instructional design, validation, and integration of instructional simulations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of instructional simulations
Applying learning theory to simulation design

courseDescription: Provides both a conceptual framework and experience in the design and development of instructional games.  The course introduces the student to the history, research, theory, and practice of instructional games.  Topics include discussions of relevant learning theories associated with instructional gaming, analysis and design of games and current research in instructional gaming.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of learning theories into game design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of research in instructional gaming
Understanding and application of relevant learning theories

courseDescription: Students will be introduced to the theoretical frameworks that form the basis of instructional systems theory and design.  Focus will be on learning theories, instructional psychology, and instructional system theory.  Recent developments in cognition, learning and instruction for educators will also be considered.  Topics include perspectives of behaviorism, social-historical constructivism, cognitive science, situated cognition, and cultural influences on cognition.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of instructional systems theory and design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex cognitive science concepts
Ability to discuss and interpret different learning theories
Understanding and discussing the cultural influences on cognition
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and apply theoretical frameworks
Analytical thinking in understanding recent developments in cognition, learning and instruction for educators
Critical evaluation of different perspectives of behaviorism
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to integrate different learning theories into instructional design
Ability to lead discussions on cognitive science and related topics

courseDescription: Problem-based course in which students gain experience applying  knowledge from IDT 749/IDT 849 to real-world instructional and instructional technology problems.  Project work is individual, paired, and in teams.  Students demonstrate mastery of the instructional design and development process through production of tools, technologies, media or materials that successfully resolve an instructional problem.  Focus is on rapid prototyping model.

Students will investigate traditional and contemporary instructional design theories and models.  Behavioral, cognitive, generative, problem-based learning, and constructivist theories as well as cognitive hierarchies will be examined, compared, contrasted and applied to various instructional situations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of instructional design theories and models
Application of cognitive hierarchies in instruction
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and comparison of instructional design theories
Problem solving through problem-based learning strategies
Evaluation and application of cognitive hierarchies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of instructional design theories to instructional situations

courseDescription: This course is a study of the application of perceptual and learning principles to the design of instructional media for use in educational and training applications.  The focus is on the development and application of heuristics from the research literature.  We will examine verbal and iconic signs as well as visual imagery, and their role in the instructional and learning processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of perceptual and learning principles
Understanding of verbal and iconic signs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of visual imagery in learning processes
Evaluation of instructional and learning processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of educational and training applications

courseDescription: Exploration and application of techniques, tools and competencies characteristic of expert designers.  Topics may include: instructional strategies, use of design software, program design, advanced analysis techniques, motivation design, rapid prototyping, reducing design cycle time, and designing instruction for diverse learner populations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Designing instruction for diverse learner populations

courseDescription: An applied survey of online instruction, including relevant theory and design considerations.  Topics include efficacy of online learning, design considerations when using course management systems and similar online learning technologies, research and future directions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing online instruction using course management systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to convey online learning efficacy
Explaining design considerations for online learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Researching and analyzing future directions in online instruction
Evaluating the efficacy of online learning

courseDescription: Introduces new Ph.D. students to the field of instructional design and technology and provides orientation to doctoral level study.  The course includes reading, critiquing and analyzing empirical research, theories, and real-world instructional problems.  Potential student research agendas consistent with faculty or programmatic research foci will be explored.  Academic and technological expectations will be communicated and practiced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of instructional design and technology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critiquing and analyzing empirical research and theories

courseTitle: Trends and Issues in Instructional Design and Technology
courseDescription: Exploration and discussion of trends and issues of current and historical significance to instructional design.  Readings will include contributions of key scholars, past and present, in instructional design and related fields.  Includes analysis of trends and issues to track and predict their impact on the future of the field.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and tracking of instructional design trends
Analyzing the impact of instructional design trends
Familiarity with key scholarly contributions in instructional design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and exploration of instructional design trends and issues
Collaborative analysis of instructional design literature
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and predicting the future impact of instructional design trends
Historical analysis of instructional design trends and issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in discussion and exploration of instructional design issues

courseTitle: Research Residency in Instructional Design and Technology
courseDescription: An introduction to conducting instructional technology research.  Students will work in consultation with their advisor to develop a proposal for a study related to instructional technology as part of their research residency that will be submitted for presentation at a nationally refereed conference or to a refereed journal.
Technical and Digital Skills: Preparation of research for submission to conferences or journals

courseTitle: Topics in Instructional Design and Technology
courseDescription: Provides opportunities for master's and doctoral students to explore topics related to instructional design.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordination of instructional design projects

courseDescription: A mentored research project by the student's advisor. Students work independently with their advisor to complete the research residency project. This course focuses on obtaining appropriate human subjects approval, collecting and analyzing data, and preparing a manuscript suitable for presentation or publication in nationally refereed journal or conference. Course may be repeated as needed, but only 3 hours may be counted toward degree requirements.
